title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care services. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with various health conditions, including children with chronic illnesses and disabilities, those living with relatives due to parental incapacity, individuals with developmental disabilities, and elders with multiple chronic conditions. Approximately 25% of the Nation's elders have multiple chronic disabling conditions, requiring assistance with daily needs. Around 600,000 Americans die at home each year, often relying on extensive family caregiving. 42% of individuals needing daily living assistance in the US are under 65. There is a lack of resources to replace family caregivers with paid workers, which would cost $200 billion annually. Family caregivers, who are mostly women, face emotional, physical, and financial hardships. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women and often struggle to find information about available respite care. The existing programs are insufficient and primarily cater to lower-income populations and elderly caregivers, leaving many without adequate support. There is a limited number of respite care programs that have difficulty recruiting trained workers. The purposes of this title are to encourage the establishment of State and local lifespan respite care programs, improve information dissemination to caregivers, and enhance respite care services. The purpose of the program is to improve respite care services for family caregivers by promoting innovative approaches, supporting research on effective services, and disseminating information on respite care delivery. The program aims to promote the dissemination of results and information related to respite care delivery, family caregiver strain, recruitment and training of respite care workers and volunteers, and training programs for family caregivers. "Definitions are outlined in section 2802." The term 'condition' includes various health and developmental issues, while an 'eligible recipient' refers to a State agency or other public entity capable of receiving assistance. An eligible recipient, as defined by regulation, can be a State agency, public entity operating statewide, nonprofit organization operating statewide, political subdivision with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, or a recognized State respite coordinating agency with demonstrated abilities in respite care and family caregiver issues. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of terms related to family caregivers and respite care, emphasizing the importance of involving family members in care decisions. The prev_chunk outlines the eligibility criteria for entities that can receive funding for respite care services. The curr_chunk defines terms related to family caregivers and special needs individuals, including the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The curr_chunk focuses on Lifespan Respite Care Grants and Cooperative Agreements under SEC. 2803. The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary may award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose. Coordination of respite care services across different agencies is emphasized, ensuring support for caregivers of individuals with special needs of all ages. The Secretary may award grants to eligible recipients for expanding respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Applicants must demonstrate understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, capacity for meaningful involvement of family members, and collaboration with other agencies. The curr_chunk provides details on the collaboration and description of family caregivers for whom respite care services will be provided, including their needs, existing services, and coordination methods at the State and local level. The curr_chunk outlines the need for coordination of respite care information and services at the State and local level, including collaboration with other related services and programs offered by public or private entities. It also discusses how grant funds will be used for respite care information dissemination, services, recruitment, and training programs for family caregivers. The curr_chunk focuses on how the proposed respite care activities will involve the population, utilize various funding sources, and address the availability of respite care services for family caregivers in the applicant's State or locality. The curr_chunk discusses respite care services for family caregivers, including improving coordination and distribution, eligibility criteria, monitoring quality and safety, and expected results. The curr_chunk outlines the necessary skills for respite care, expected results, and confidentiality assurances. The Secretary will establish a review panel to evaluate applications for respite care services. The Secretary will establish a panel to review and evaluate applications for respite care services, making recommendations for approval. Grants or cooperative agreements will be awarded based on the panel's recommendations, with priority given to those enhancing lifespan respite care statewide. Recipients must agree to use funds for developing respite care at the State and local levels. The Secretary awards grants or cooperative agreements for developing respite care services at the State and local levels, including worker training and program evaluation. Recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies for implementation. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 5 years and may be renewed. The Secretary awards grants or cooperative agreements for respite care services for up to 5 years, with the possibility of renewal. Funds must supplement, not replace, other available federal, state, and local funds. The Secretary awards grants for respite care services for up to 5 years, with the possibility of renewal, to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care. The Center's duties include maintaining a national database, providing training and technical assistance, and offering information and educational programs on lifespan respite care. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this title.
